attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Each polygon/record was given a unique ID number ranging from 101 to 400.
Name of the GRSG Population the PAC is located in. Population name references the 'GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_Populations' data set.
Management Zone each PAC is within. Management Zone number references the 'GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_MgmtZones' data set.
Unique name created by combining Unique ID number, population name, and Management Zone information.
Geometry calculated to provide the acres in each polygon.
Area of feature in internal units squared.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.2.1.3497
dataIdInfo.idPurp: This data set represents greater sage-grouse Priority Areas for Conservation (PACs) to be used in work for the USFWS 2015 Status Review for the greater sage-grouse. As defined by the 2013 Greater Sage-Grouse Conservation Objectives Team (COT) Report, PACs identify important areas for the long term persistence of sage-grouse and areas to focus conservation efforts.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This polygon data set represents all sage-grouse Priority Areas for Conservation (PACs) identified in the 2013 Greater Sage-Grouse Conservation Objectives Team (COT) Report. PACs represent areas identified as essential for the long-term conservation of the sage-grouse. The COT determined that the PACs are key for the conservation of the species range wide.

PAC polygons were provided by States. This data set has merged all State PACs together and cleaned up the polygons by filling in small gaps along state borders, closing any holes less than 10 acres, and removing any polygons less than 10 acres. This cleaning reduced noise in the data. PACs were then split by population using the ‘GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_Populations’ population data set. PACs also attributed with a unique ID number, Population, Management Zone, unique ID name, and acres. See the Supplemental Information for more details. For more information on how States compiled their data please see the 2013 Greater Sage-Grouse Conservation Objectives Team Report and/or the 2013_GSGCOT_PAC data.

9/25/2014 - Updated by adding an additional PAC polygon in Montana. Additional PAC developed and supplied by Montana Fish, Wildlife, and Parks.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: US Fish and Wildlife Service (Wyoming Ecological Services) , 2014 – Scott Gardner, California Fish and Wildlife | BLM Eagle Lake Field Office | USGS Western Ecological Research Center | Kathy Griffin, Colorado Parks and Wildlife | Idaho Department of Fish and Game | Rick Northrup, Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks | Aaron Robinson, North Dakota Game and Fish | State of Nevada | Oregon Fish and Wildlife | BLM, South Dakota Field Office (Belle Fourche, SD) | Utah Division of Wildlife Resources | Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife, Mike Schroeder | Wyoming Game and Fish Department | Bob Budd, State of Wyoming | USGS | BLM

Consts.useLimit: Although these data and information have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USFWS, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data and information on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data, and information, and aggregate use with other data and information. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data and information. The USFWS shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data and information described and/or contained herein.

dataIdInfo.suppInfo:
Started with the PAC data defined by the 2013 COT Report. PAC data was grouped by state as PAC data was supplied by each individual state. This ‘GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_PACs’ data set meant to merge all PACs into one layer and clean it to provide one range wide PAC data set to be used in work for the USFWS 2015 Status Review for the greater sage-grouse.
• All PAC layers from the 2013 COT Report merged together and dissolved across state boundaries.
• Small gaps were filled in and errors removed along state borders.
• All holes smaller than 10 acres were closed.
• All polygons smaller than 10 acres were removed (some data sets from the states included very small sliver polygons that should not be included and created noise in the data. This noise was cleaned by removing polygons less than 10 acres).
• PACs were than split along population boundaries using the ‘GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_Populations’ data set.
• Attribute information added o ‘UniqueID’ field added where each polygon was given a unique ID number ranging from 101 to 401 (301 total PAC polygons). o ‘Population’ field added and attributed with the Population name each polygon overlaid. o ‘MgmtZone’ field added and attributed with the Management Zone each polygon overlaid. o ‘ID_Name’ field added and attributed by combing all information from the ‘UniqueID,’ ‘Population,’ and ‘MgmtZone’ fields. o ‘Acres’ field added and geometry was calculated to provide the acres in each polygon.

LegConsts.useLimit: Although these data and information have been processed successfully on a computer system at the USFWS, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data and information on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data, and information, and aggregate use with other data and information. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data and information. The USFWS shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data and information described and/or contained herein.

descript.abstract:
This polygon data set represents all sage-grouse Priority Areas for Conservation (PACs) identified in the 2013 Greater Sage-Grouse Conservation Objectives Team (COT) Report. PACs represent areas identified as essential for the long-term conservation of the sage-grouse. The COT determined that the PACs are key for the conservation of the species range wide. PAC polygons were provided by States. This data set has merged all State PACs together and cleaned up the polygons by filling in small gaps along state borders, closing any holes less than 10 acres, and removing any polygons less than 10 acres. This cleaning reduced noise in the data. PACs were then split by population using the ‘GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_Populations’ population data set. PACs also attributed with a unique ID number, Population, Management Zone, unique ID name, and acres. See the Supplemental Information for more details. For more information on how States compiled their data please see the 2013 Greater Sage-Grouse Conservation Objectives Team Report and/or the 2013_GSGCOT_PAC data.
9/25/2014 - Updated by adding an additional PAC polygon in Montana. Additional PAC developed and supplied by Montana Fish, Wildlife, and Parks.
descript.purpose: This data set represents greater sage-grouse Priority Areas for Conservation (PACs) to be used in work for the USFWS 2015 Status Review for the greater sage-grouse. As defined by the 2013 Greater Sage-Grouse Conservation Objectives Team (COT) Report, PACs identify important areas for the long term persistence of sage-grouse and areas to focus conservation efforts.
descript.supplinf:
Started with the PAC data defined by the 2013 COT Report. PAC data was grouped by state as PAC data was supplied by each individual state. This ‘GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_PACs’ data set meant to merge all PACs into one layer and clean it to provide one range wide PAC data set to be used in work for the USFWS 2015 Status Review for the greater sage-grouse.
• All PAC layers from the 2013 COT Report merged together and dissolved across state boundaries.
• Small gaps were filled in and errors removed along state borders.
• All holes smaller than 10 acres were closed.
• All polygons smaller than 10 acres were removed (some data sets from the states included very small sliver polygons that should not be included and created noise in the data. This noise was cleaned by removing polygons less than 10 acres).
• PACs were than split along population boundaries using the ‘GRSG_2015_USFWS_StatusReview_Populations’ data set.
• Attribute information added o ‘UniqueID’ field added where each polygon was given a unique ID number ranging from 101 to 401 (301 total PAC polygons). o ‘Population’ field added and attributed with the Population name each polygon overlaid. o ‘MgmtZone’ field added and attributed with the Management Zone each polygon overlaid. o ‘ID_Name’ field added and attributed by combing all information from the ‘UniqueID,’ ‘Population,’ and ‘MgmtZone’ fields. o ‘Acres’ field added and geometry was calculated to provide the acres in each polygon.
